Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal deals with studying ``Heegaard Floer homology,'' the new invariants for three-and four-dimensional spaces constructed by the investigator in collaboration with Zoltan Szabo. These invariants give new insight into earlier invariants for spaces constructed using ``gauge theoretic'' techniques: the Donaldson and Seiberg-Witten invariants. In addition, they can be used to address older topological questions, including specifically questions about Dehn surgery on classical knots. This project aims to understand these invariants better, in veiw of recent computational advances in the theory, and to give further applications to knot theory and the topology of three- and four-dimensional manifolds.


The introduction of equations with origins in mathematical physics has has lead to great advances in our understanding of the topoligical properties of three and four-dimensional spaces over the past twenty years. Further progress in this area is facilitated by an alternative, more geometric understanding of the data derived from these equations, known as ``Heegaard Floer homology'', a new theory developed by the investigator in collaboration with Zoltan Szabo. Heegaard Floer homology has already shed new light on the structure of three- and four-dimensional spaces. These new methods have been the object of study of the investigator, and the present proposal deals further developments using these techniques.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project centers on "Heegaard Floer homology", a way of using new techniques from various branches of mathematics (but especially symplectic geometry) to study low-dimensional phenomena. The most accessible of these low-dimensional phenomena perhaps is the problem of how closed loops can knot in three-dimensional space ("knot theory"). Heegaard Floer homology gives a certificate which one can associate to a low-dimensional object (such as a knotted loop) which encodes properties of that object. As a direct result of the project, these certificates have become much more computable. These methods have lead to a very active field drawing a new generation of young mathematicians to studying these new techniques for solving old questions in topology.

The project directly resulted in published articles in several related directions. One of these directions, "bordered Floer homology" equips Heegaard Floer homology with richer algebraic structure, both rendering more computable and opening new interactions between topology and the field of differential graded algebra.  The resulting publications are joint with Robert Lipshitz and Dylan Thurston. Another of these directions, "knot Floer homology", underscores the interaction with Heegaard Floer homology and knot theory. The resulting papers are joint with Zoltan Szabo, with whom Heegaard Floer homology was originally constructed. Further computational schemes for knot Floer homology were discovered in collaboration with Ciprian Manolescu, Sucharit Sarkar, and Dylan Thurston. In a third direction, Heegaard Floer homology can be connected with another modern branch of geometry called "contact geometry". With its origins in classical mechanics, contact geometry is experiencing a new rennaissance, owing to its connections to other parts of mathematics. A connection with Heegaard Floer homology was first discovered in connection with Zoltan Szabo and further explored in collaboration with Andras Stipsicz.

 


Last Modified: 06/11/2012
Modified by: Peter S Ozsvath
